comments:
Hi,

Possible bug in Eclipse in editor action contribution here?

Basically, when I right-click on the active text editor, I will have a menu 
entry that will invoke my plugin to work on the contents of the file being 
edited.  Everything works great; however, if I, instead, double-clicked on an 
the file from the package explorer view, I get the below errors.

Errors shown in the console view output by Eclipse:

Could not create action delegate for id: com.xyz.actions.MyEditorAction
Reason:
Internal plug-in action delegate error on creation.
Could not create action delegate for id: com.xyz.actions.MyEditorAction
Reason:
Internal plug-in action delegate error on creation.



Here is my editor contribution snippet in the plugin.xml file:

<extension point="org.eclipse.ui.popupMenus">
      <viewerContribution
         id="com.xyz.EditorActions"
         targetID="#TextEditorContext">
         <action
            id="com.xyz.actions.MyEditorAction"
            label="%externalizerMenu"
            icon="icons/MyIcon16.gif"
            menubarPath="additions"
            class="com.xyz.actions.MyEditorAction">
         </action>
      </viewerContribution>
   </extension>
And what is in the log?

(In reply to comment #1)
> And what is in the log?

Nothing says in the log...That's why it so puzzling...Here is exactly what is 
done in my plugin.

(1) I contributed the editor action as described in the original message.

(2) When the user chooses the contributed action from an editor by right-
clicking the mouse in the editor view, I do some stuff and at the overwrite 
the file from the IFile instance that I got when the action kicked in.  After 
I have written the file, I do the below call.

MyIFileInstance.getProject().refreshLocal(IResource.DEPTH_INFINITE, p_monitor);

(3) Now go back to the package explorer where the file is and double-click on 
it.  You will see the problem.

Have you check the log for your self-hosted session (i.e., the session in which
the problem occurred)?  Alternatively, have you check the "Error Log" view? 
There will be an exception there....

(In reply to comment #3)
> Have you check the log for your self-hosted session (i.e., the session in 
which
> the problem occurred)?  Alternatively, have you check the "Error Log" view? 
> There will be an exception there....

Yes, I check the log in my .metadata directory and also the "Error Log" view.  
They are identical.  I stepped in the debugger and the problem is in the 
module PluginAction.java in

<eclipse_root>\plugins\org.eclipse.platform.source_3.0.0
\src\org.eclipse.ui.workbench_3.0.0\org\eclipse\ui\internal

It happens precisly in the method "protected final void createDelegate()"...It 
just logs the error messages into the console as posted in my original post.

A little more info...

I found the mentioned problem when doing a double-click on the resource, a 
file (an IFile).  Below is my action class.

public class MyEditorAction extends ActionDelegate implements
		IEditorActionDelegate
{
   public void setActiveEditor(IAction action, IEditorPart targetEditor)
   {
      ...
   }
}

The problem is that AFTER I have written/updated the file on the first time, 
be it double-clicking on the file in the package explorer view or open the 
file with an editor, double-clicking it on a second time will have 
setActiveEditor(...) called again.  However, this second call 
has 'targetEditor' set to *null*.  Because I use the 'targetEditor', a null 
exception is generated, thus, PluginAction.java generated the errors mentioned.

My question is:  Why 'targetEditor' is null after the first time?

Thanks

Can you put a breakpoint on EclipseLog.writeStack(FrameworkLogEntry) [found in
"org.eclipse.core.runtime"]?  Please let me know what the throwable is....

If that doesn't work, set a breakpoint at the first line of the catch block in
PluginAction.createDelegate().

(BTW, you can get the stack trace of an exception by making a watch expression
like "e.printStackTrace()")

Here you go:

 Unfortunately, this bug is not currently on the plan for 3.1.  It might be
addressed after 3.1 ships.
